instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_MANUAL_RST_L: What is SMC_MANUAL_RST_L? SMC_MANUAL_RST_L resets the SMC when low.   _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_PWRBTNL_L: What is PM_PWRBTNL_L? This is a typo of PM_PWRBTN_L When you see PM_PWRBTNL_L, assume they meant to type PM_PWRBTN_L.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message:
Hi all. Not posted for a while as I seem to be getting on OK with the logic board repairs. However, I think I am not seeing the wood for the tree's. I am searching around and losing track of what, where, why and when.
MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
Magsafe- Green to Orange- no power on- no fan spin
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.597v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.428v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.307V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V

Basically, all the 3v3 rails are 0v

I have seen this issue addressed a few times on the forum and by our "leader" but for the life of me I can't seem to locate any of the videos or posts. I am probably not putting in the right search terms but being thick.. who knows.

My deduction, I believe there is an IC that produces both the 5v and the 3.3v.

Searched over the board and so far, there was corrosion around pins 18 to 21 on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> so I removed and replaced it with another.
Corrosion around pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R4411</RESISTOR> and all 6 pins on <TRANSISTOR>Q4410</TRANSISTOR>. <TRANSISTOR>Q4410</TRANSISTOR> was replaced. Pad on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R4411</RESISTOR> was gone so jumped to pin 1 on <RESISTOR>R4410</RESISTOR>.
checked rest of the board.... no corrosion. I don't think the board has been looked at before as even though it is cleaner that I would have thought as there was a little corrosion, there are loads of fibres on the board giving me reason to believe it has not been ultrasonic cleaned.

Prior to disassembly, I did do a SMC reset and a PRAM reset. I have also tested <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> which gives 3.384v and <SIGNAL>SMC_MANUAL_RST_L</SIGNAL> gives 2.754v

When the magsafe i connected the CPU does get warm. And even though I do not believe for one second it is a contributing factor, I have "carefully" removed J6100. I don't know why but Louis seems to have good results removing this.

Is there anything else I should be checking, please?
Thank you in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message:
Hiya, as an update, if it helps, I have followed page 62 of the schematic down and below are all the voltages of the first line of all the power rails.

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>= 3.356v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>= 5.036v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>= 3.357v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>= 3.355v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD</SIGNAL>= 0v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>= 1.066v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL>= 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBTLC</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_TBTCIO</SIGNAL>= 0v

Unfortunately, I do not have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here to make a comparison with. 
Just in case I was being trolled, I have also changed the DC-in board and the charge ribbon.

Please help oh guru's of the mac world.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message: Voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>? Any history liquid drop etc?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message:
No reason to check S0 voltages, when missing S3 voltages.
Keep in mind, power sequence is S5 --> S3 --> S0.

Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTNL_L</SIGNAL> reacts when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
If you get a pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, all S3 voltages should pulse too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message:
[USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER]

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>= 3.303v

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTNL_L</SIGNAL>..... did you mean <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>? If so I get 3.383v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message:
[USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] 
Just managed to get in touch with the customer, he "claims" he has dropped it twice from a low level onto carpet. Last time was about 18 months ago. Dont know if that has any bearing on the diagnostics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message:
Dropped machines are always nightmare to repair.

"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>= 0.036v"
PCH will not start power sequence in this way.
Are you surely using original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger?

"<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTNL_L</SIGNAL>..... did you mean <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>? If so I get 3.383v"
Sorry for misspelling.
I was asking for any reaction; it is steady high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message: You ARE NOT Using a genuine charger BATLOW should be 3.3! Go get an OEM 85 watt MagSafe 2 from Apple or Best Buy before continuing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message:
[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] I tested the voltage at probe point 639 ( just below <RESISTOR>R2223</RESISTOR>) ( as shown using Landrex ( i like Landrex)) and it showed 0.036v. I felt this was easier to locate than <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR>. However, when I tested at Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> I was getting the same 0.036v but pin 1 is showing 3.334v. I removed this resistor and replaced it with another 10 kOhm resistor and now getting 3.330v on pin 2 and fan spin using both my 60w and 85w Magsafe 2 adapters.... no Magsafe 1 to 2 convertor as this sometimes gives problems. I am going to reassemble to see what happens from here and will report back

[USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] All of my adapters are genuine adapters. With exception of my 60w and 85w Magsafe 1's, which came from units that I brought in, my 45/60/85w Magsafe 2 and 30w USB C all came from my local Apple store at Lakeside Thurrock in Essex, UK. I have been caught out with this before when [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] was troubleshooting another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board I had in for repair.

I am putting it back together and wil let you know the result.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message: And there we have it... got a fan spin, a boot and folder displayed. I am going to re-attach the J6100 connector as I feel that it really was of no consequence to the issue. For the record parts swapped were <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q4410</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R4411</RESISTOR>. Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R4411</RESISTOR> was also jumped to pin 1 on <RESISTOR>R4410</RESISTOR>. Finally <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> was replaced. I am going to soak test it for a couple of hours to make sure all is good. Thank you both for your assistance in helping me see the problems and resolving then. Kudos to you both.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message:
Good job!

Don't waste time with J6100, not really needed.
It only helps to flash the BIOS onboard...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v or 3v3.
threads.message: Thank you [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] . I have fitted it back before i saw your message. As usual, I couldn't have done this without the aid of you guys on the forum.
